page.title: 19 NATURAL HISTORY
page.content: The meadows around the Coombe Hill Canal are flooded on average for two months each year. During the winter counts of 3,000 Wigeon, 1,000 Mallard and several hundred Shovellers, Pintails, and a few Gadwall, Teal and Bewick Swan are made; these birds migrating from the Arctic. In the summer the area is a breeding ground for Curlews, Redshanks, Lapwings and Snipe. The hedgerows are mainly Hawthorn which provides food for winter Redwing and Fieldfare and summer nesting for Willow Warbler, Whitethroat,Thrushes and Green Woodpecker. Along the Coombe Hill Canal is the habitat of the Yellow Wagtail. Some Kestrel which feed on voles and beetles are to be seen but a lot have moved nearer to the M.5.Motorway.
